awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a nanofiber cloth to filter carcinogenic chemicals such as formaldehyde when used in face masks. The innovation can be adapted for other airborne carcinogenic chemicals (e.g., benzene, toluene, and ammonia) detection and prevention. This innovation will have commercial and societal benefits and applications for various industries, including health, education, and fuel delivery. The project's interdisciplinary nature will advance electrospun nanotechnology, material characterization, and experimental techniques.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a filter fabric for a facemask or air filter, which will absorb airborne formaldehyde and pathogens, preventing human exposure. This project will use an electrospun nanofiber mesh technology to produce a unique, biofriendly fabric incorporating formaldehyde absorption and antibacterial agents. This fabric will be capable of filtering out airborne pathogenic molecules less than 120 nm. Electrospinning is an engineering process by which threads 1000 times less than a spider web can be processed into a non-woven fabric. The nanofibers have been used to coat implants (e.g., dental, knee, and bone anchor) and produce antibacterial bandages, bones, skin grafts, and intervertebral discs. The outcome of this project is an improved, cost-effective, and bio-friendly filtration material and production technology that will impact human health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
We are exploring a groundbreaking smart filtration system aimed at combating the pervasive issue of airborne formaldehyde, a hazardous volatile organic compound (VOC) known for its adverse health effects. Our innovative solution, supported by the I-corp award, has led to the customer discovery for the development of a polymeric electrospun nanofiber (ENF)-membrane utilizing electrospun nanofiber technology. Our ENF Filter creation venture, led by Dr. Morshed Khandaker, along with co-founders Mr. Hussein Alizereej and Mr. Sadegh Nikfarjam, brings together a wealth of expertise in electrospun nanofiber technology, engineering, and microbiology. Their collaboration with the University of Central Oklahoma and University of Texas-Rio Grande Valley for further research and development underscores the project's commitment to innovation and excellence.

Our market research has highlighted a substantial need for VOC absorbent filtration systems, with significant opportunities identified within the indoor air quality and global air purifier markets. The system's potential for impact is particularly notable in environments where VOC exposure is prevalent, such as university and hospital chemical and pathology labs, offering a critical solution to an urgent health and safety issue. A total of 133 interviews during NSF i-corp programs with university and hospital pathology lab directors, funeral home managers and owners and the director of chemical labs were found out that the worker’s health is at risk because their workplace does not provide any protection (use standard surgical or the room has an open vent without filters) from VOCs. In funeral and cremation service, 90% of the interviewee were not wearing masks and the space lacked ventilation. In the pathology labs, 89% of interviewee were wearing a surgical mask and do not work under hood. Funeral homes and pathology labs in hospitals, universities, and diagnostic centers account for 36,000 and 312,000 of our immediate direct clients, respectively.

Our air filtration system is a versatile product that can be targeted towards various industries, including healthcare, hospital, education, residential, commercial, industrial, and military. Our innovative filter membrane can absorb VOCs from the air, marking a significant advancement in air purification technology, particularly benefiting workers in university and hospital pathology lab workers who are at a heightened risk of exposure. The core of this technological innovation is the electrospinning process, which creates ultra-fine fibers capable of capturing airborne particles, including formaldehyde, with exceptional efficiency. During this I-corp award, the project faced and overcame several technical hurdles, including developing a VOC-absorbent membrane through the I-corp prototype development fund. Our goal was to design a cloth that can provide adequate airflow while effectively absorbing formaldehyde and ensuring the durability and manufacturability of the nanofiber cloth.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its potential to significantly improve human health by providing a reliable means of filtering and detecting harmful VOCs, including formaldehyde. By leveraging the unique properties of electrospun nanofibers, the team has introduced a novel solution that surpasses the capabilities of existing air filters, which primarily block only dust particles.

The broader impacts of this work are far-reaching, offering benefits across various sectors including healthcare, education, and beyond. The project's success in developing a versatile and effective filtration system opens up possibilities for detecting and preventing exposure to a wide array of airborne carcinogens, contributing to a safer and healthier environment for all. Through its interdisciplinary approach and collaboration with industry partners, the project also fosters innovation and technological advancement, further highlighting the significant societal benefits of this research.

 


Last Modified: 04/08/2024
Modified by: Morshed P Khandaker
